I absolutely loved all of the excursions we had in this class as it brought what we were learning to life. It was also nice to learn information from the tour guides while actually being in the sites we were studying. Overall, it was very engaging.
Material was interesting but we never really saw anything in depth, which I would have liked.

We discussed a lot of interesting works and concepts in this course, from Italian poems to the Siena Palio to the history and significance of the city of Livorno. I was engaged with it every day, despite being exhausted from all the traveling I was conducting over the summer, and there was always a new concept to get excited about learning every afternoon. I would have liked to cover more material, as there seem to be some major concepts listed on the Syllabus that we never got around to learning about.

One of the greatest strengths of the course is the fact that we take trips to different places in order to witness and learn more about what we had discussed in class previously. I feel like these trips definitely helped in enhancing my understanding as well as providing me with the opportunity to learn more than I would have if we had just had lessons every day. I furthermore thought the reading materials provided and the ability to write on topics of our own choice made the course a lot more enjoyable and provided an opportunity to get creative and not feel limited.

The weakness of this course was its inconsistent format.  I was happy to experience so many excursions outside the classroom -- visits to Livorno, Rome, San Gimignano, the contrada museum, the bottini, the Duomo, other churches, Lo Spedale, and many other locations -- but the in-classroom aspect of the course was so disjointed among these many excursions that it was difficult to establish consistent or prolonged engagement with any one topic.  I might have preferred to cover fewer specific topics for a bit longer of a period.  Normally, I am happy to experience as many insights about as many different things as possible, but in this case it struck me as slightly pointless to, for example, engage with the Decameron for just a single day.  While it's true that even relatively brief engagement with some topics inspired me to want to learn more, it was slightly frustrating that such learning would have to be done on my own rather than in Italian in the midst of Tuscany during the summer program.

The strength of the program was its focus on topics that were so different from each other.  I appreciated how the curriculum was not only centered on Sienese history or traditions, but also featured emphases on Rome, Florence, Livorno, and important texts and artworks from all around Medieval Tuscany.  Such an experience provided a more holistic approach than I was expecting and exposed me to the great differences in perspective, tradition, and lifestyle of various areas of Italy.
I felt that I learned more when we learned about topics from presentations and class discussions rather than just intensive and lengthy readings.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student as it provides crucial knowledge to understand what's happening within Siena and gives a fundamental basis to understand Italian at a more profound level. I would recommend this course to another student as long as it was being taken in Siena.  I think the course would fail to offer nearly as much engagement or relevance if taken in New Haven or some other location where the student would not be exposed firsthand to the art, history, and customs about which they would learn.
